large left sock background/introduction decorative welt also known as a tuck it adds color and texture to garments its construction is both challenging and fiddly yet is rewarding once its final maneuver is completed written instructions are provided for reference a westknits demonstration is linked in the glossary showing the welt being knit flat the socks decorative welts are created in the round ruching ruching uses pleated fluted or gathered fabric strips to create a ripple-like effect to achieve this trick with yarn a technique is used to integrate sets of row whose stitch counts abruptly increase and decrease combined with changes in needle size a framed edge provides stability to the ruching panel which runs up the center back length of the leg © mary pat mcgurk 2023 v 1 5 2 3-colored slip_stitch heel the heel is stretchy widthwise but due to the slip_stitch placements the heel length shortens this increases the number of row required to achieve a satisfactory heel flap length the number of stitches for the gusset pick up is commensurate to one s usual sock size knitting gusset stitches are picked up from the wrong side of the heel flap a video link is provided in the glossary as well as photos of the pick-up method used by the designer any method that picks up stitches from the backside of the heel flap should be acceptable knitters may pick the one that best suits them palestrina knots long admired is the work of anna zilboorg she often uses palestrina knots to embellish 3 stitch clusters of which the gathering sock has many a tutorial video link of their construction is provided on page 889 the gathering socks design makes a revision to run the connecting thread between each knot along the ws of the fabric rather than the rs an explanation of how to work the revised knots for these socks follows the link the palestrina knots are best added before closing the toes the embroidery does not add
